utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: What brings you in to see us?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: So I've just been having this cough that I feel has just been getting worse, and I've also been feeling a bit short of breath for the last few months.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: OK, could you tell me when the cough started?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: So I would say it started around two months ago.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: OK, and has the cough been dry or have you been bringing up sputum?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: Uh, it's usually always, uh, produces like the sputum, and it's usually white or yellowish in colour.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: OK, and how much sputum are you producing each day? Some, sometimes it's useful to think about like teaspoons or tablespoons.

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: I would say every time I cough like a teaspoon I probably have like. I don't know. Maybe 5 to 10 teaspoons a day.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: Uh OK, and is there any particular time of day that the cough is worse?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: Um, not really. It's pretty, pretty much the same. Sometimes it is worse in the morning. Yeah, and sometimes it gets better when I go out for a smoke.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: OK um. And have you noticed any blood?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: No, um I haven't noticed any blood.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: OK, and have you had, so you had shortness of breath, when did that start?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: It's around two months ago, around the same time.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: OK, And. Is this? Do you have shortness of breath at rest or is it when you exert yourself?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: Uh, it's it can happen like at anytime, but worse when I am exerting myself.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: OK and then have you had a cough before?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: Uh. Not as frequently. I would say not really, it just started in the last two to three months.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: OK, and have you had shortness of breath like this before?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: Just throughout my life I've had asthma so when I am exercising too much or get exposed to like dust, sometimes get shortness of breath.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: OK. Has there been anything, um besides exerting yourself, that's made that either the cough or or shortness of breath worse?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: Uh, over the last year like I've had a couple of chest infections. After going to the ER, they gave me some antibiotics. But yeah, when that happens it usually gets worse. The shortness of breath and the cough.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: OK, and uh, do your symptoms feel like any of those times right now?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: No, I I don't feel like I have a fever and no other symptoms, just the shortness of breath and cough.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: OK, and have you been doing anything that's made it better?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: I've been taking some Tylenol Cold, hasn't really helped too much. I've tried my inhalers, they sometimes help, but I've never had have this frequent of coughing and shortness of breath before.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: OK, um, and how has your energy been? Have you been experiencing fatigue?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: Um, when it gets really bad then I can't really step out of the house, but other than that I feel like my energy's still there.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: OK and you have it, have you had any fevers or chills?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: No.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: OK, how about at a loss of smell?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: No.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: Um a loss of taste?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: Nope.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: OK, and have you had any chest pain?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: No, just sometimes when I'm like coughing a lot it gets a little bit uncomfortable. But other than that, no.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: OK, um have you had any instances where you felt like your heart was racing?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: No.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: OK, how about being lightheaded or or like you were going to pass out?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: No.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: OK, have you had a runny nose or or a sore throat?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: Nope.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: OK, and how about headaches?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: No headaches.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: Alright, and have you had any wheezing?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: Um, sometimes I've noticed it, but I had it before. Like with asthma as well, but not not that much.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: OK, and how about abdominal pain?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: No abdominal pain.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: Alright, then any urinary problems?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: Nope.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: Any bowel problems?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: No.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: Any rashes?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: Nope.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: OK, and then how about any muscle aches or or joint aches or or body aches?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: No, nothing like that.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: Alright. And you mentioned asthma, but have you been diagnosed with any other medical conditions?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: No, just asthma.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: OK, and do you use inhalers? Are there any other medications you're currently using?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: Oh no, just the salbutamol and like the steroid inhaler.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: OK, yeah, and how often are you using both of those?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: So the steroid one I am using pretty much every day but the salbutamol I found I've been using a lot more recently. I would say probably at least six to 10 times in a week.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: OK, um that reminded me I I forgot to ask. Have you notice any changes to your voice?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: Um no, not really.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: OK um. And I was wondering if you had any allergies to medications?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: No, not that I know of.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: Alright, and have you been in the hospital recently?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: No.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: Alright, so when was the last time that you had antibiotics?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: I would say like six months ago.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: OK and any surgeries?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: Nope.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: OK, and did you get the flu shot this year?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: Yep.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: OK, great um and I was wondering if you could tell me a little bit about your living situation.

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: So I live in London um in a small apartment with my wife.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: OK, do you have any pets around?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: No, no pets.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: Alright, and um, any exposures at work too, like dust or any types of like chemicals like that.

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: No, not really. My work is pretty much a desk job, so nothing like that.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: OK, and do you smoke cigarettes?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: Yeah yeah, I smoke a lot of cigarettes just like I would say 30 cigarettes a day.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: OK, and how long have you smoked for?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: I'd say, probably at least 25 years.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: OK and sorry, could you remind me of your your age again?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: So I am 60 years old now.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: OK, so you started smoking um around 35.

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: Yeah yeah.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: OK. Have you tried to quit?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: Yeah, tried to quit. I've even quite a couple times but then just got back onto it. Yeah, not not really ready to quit.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: OK. That's fair enough. If there's something that you wanted to talk about quitting smoking at another appointment, we can arrange follow up for that.

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: Alright

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: Do you drink alcohol?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: Not much, just out say one or two beers on the weekend.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: Alright, and you use any recreational drugs like cocaine, crystal meth, or IV drugs.

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: No, nothing like that.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: Alright, and has anything similar like this happened in your family before?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: Uh, I think my um sister has a COPD, like she smokes a lot too. But that's that's about, I don't know if that's genetic.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: Oh OK, um I. So I mean anybody in the family have cancers?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: Um no, not that I know of.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: Alright um so, that that was all the questions that I wanted to ask on history. Was there any, uh, any other questions that you had?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: No, not really. Just wanted to get to the bottom of this.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: OK for sure so um we will run some investigations and likely get a chest X Ray because it's been a couple of months that these symptoms have been going on for. But I think it could be related to your smoking and most likely um Bronc, chronic bronchitis, but we can definitely will be looking into this, and then also with possibly some pulmonary function tests as well.

utterances.speaker: control
utterances.text: Add differential diagnosis
